subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello, I’m Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I’d like to talk about
Unidentified Flying Objects, a fascinating topic.
Now, if you’ve watched
segment number 16 of the “In Presence” series on psychokinesis, you’ll note that I report an
experiment, in which I was engaged in, that produced one of the most well-attested UFO sightings in history.
But I have to tell you, I have avoided the UFO community,
UFO symposiums,
professional UFO
organizations, largely because there’s sort of a circus atmosphere that surrounds this phenomenon.
I don’t think that the particular case in which I was involved has actually received much notice
from the ufological
community. I’d also like to point out to you that if you look at the upper right-hand corner of your screen
right now, you’ll see a link to an interview
I conducted with Jacques Vallée about 30 years ago, believe it or not.
Jacques Vallée is probably the leading thinker in the area of
UFOs, and the interview that I did with him so long ago –
I believe – is still quite relevant. He’s almost a mythological
person, in the sense that a character was fashioned after him in the classic movie Close Encounters of the Third Kind.
The main point that I’d like to make in discussing UFOs is
that, in my opinion, it’s not a single phenomenon.
It’s very likely many, many, different kinds of phenomena get lumped together in this category.
For example,
there’s good reason to think that some UFOs, and perhaps the ones that I have reported on, are
psychological projections, or, to be more specific,
psychokinetic projections. A classic example of that, which is very clear-cut, is
presented in The Roots of Consciousness. It’s the case of Stella
Lansing, a
schizophrenic woman, actually, who was studied by the psychiatrist Berthold Schwarz. She had “thoughtographic”
capabilities, and she was able to take many pictures of
UFOs. She pointed her camera into the sky and snapped pictures,
and they would be in a clock-like pattern, maybe a dozen of them, as if they were the part of
the dial of a watch. Now, nobody else could see them, but they’d show up on the film, and it’s pretty clear these were
“thoughtographic”, or “psychographic”, or psychokinetic projections from her mind.
It’s also important to note that in the case of Ted Owens, and in the case of Uri Geller, two individuals with
extraordinary
psychokinetic
capacities, both of them have a story in which it would appear that
UFOs are somehow
instrumental in the unfolding of their unusual abilities. Jacques Vallée, of course,
equates UFOs to
sightings that have been reported for centuries
throughout humanity.
I guess we can’t overlook the
possibility that UFOs really do represent space
vehicles from other planets. There’s good reason to think that might be true as well,
particularly military sightings and the fact that UFOs seem to be, in some way,
interested in
U.S.
atomic weaponry and U.S. missile
systems.
Then again, there are those who hypothesize that these craft might be secret aircraft, either
from the United States, or perhaps from our allies, or even our enemies.
UFOs have been in the news a lot lately. It’s been reported that
the military has been
taking an interest in UFOs,
t ironically, the military interest, as far as we know, these days, is
largely to determine whether they
present a national security threat.
It seems as if the military has concluded that, whatever they are, they do not threaten our national security.
Jacques Vallée would suggest that UFOs represent part of a control
system, that they’ve been
shaping human culture at a subconscious level, maybe for thousands of years.
There’s the work of Zecharia Sitchin, a
translator of ancient Sumerian texts. He argues that
the gods of ancient Sumeria are actually beings who came to Earth in UFOs, and performed genetic
experiments, mixing their own genes with the genes of
native apes that existed on this planet,
and that’s what gave birth to the human species as we know it today.
That’s a very different theory than either
Darwinian evolution or biblical creation.
I think the evidence for that is rather thin, but I don’t think we can rule it out at this point.
My close friend Saul-Paul Sirag
is a person
who has been interested in UFOs ever since I first met him back in the early 1970s.
We attended a number of UFO symposiums together
back in those days. He proposes that UFOs might well be ourselves
from the future. Future humans time-traveling back to the present, and
probably, as such, very, very careful not to interfere too much with our present
society.
Another
possibility, suggested to me by Ted Owens, the PK Man who I studied for 10 years, is
that they represent
hyperspace beings, not from another planet
but from another dimension of space. I can say that there’s a great deal of
mathematical research, physical research, particularly in the area of “String Theory”,
“Membrane Theory” – cutting-edge ideas and physics today –
that suggest
higher dimensions of space.
“Hyperspace”, as it is sometimes known, is a very real prospect. We’ve barely
begun to understand the implications of this, and how it might be related to human consciousness and
UFOs. And,
finally, I think we have to take the “trickster” archetype into account.
UFOs may very well represent complex patterns that are simply so
outrageous as to
defy all
rational
understanding. Let me give you an example of my own encounter with the trickster archetype. This occurred back around
1978. I was invited with a small group of people
to attend a UFO gathering, a private gathering, in Twentynine Palms,
California, in the Mojave Desert. With us was a lady,
named Valerie as I recall, who had actually worked in the
White House of Gerald Ford, in the ‘Whip Inflation Now”
program.
She had a White House position, but she was something of a trance medium, and believed that she had
telepathic connections with who she referred to as “the boys upstairs,”
meaning
beings associated with UFOs. She had brought this group of people together in Southern
California for the purpose of having an actual,
physical encounter. She went into a trance and
said, one day, “The encounter will occur this evening, about 4:00 in the morning. We’re going to get up,
we’re going to ride out in jeeps way into the middle of the desert. There, the UFOs are going to land,
and they will meet us.” So we did, at 4:00 in the morning, caravanning in two jeeps, about a dozen people,
in the middle of the Mojave Desert. I can tell you, my jaw
dropped
when I saw
four bright lights slowly
descending to the desert floor, maybe as close as half a mile away from us.
Unbelievable! I thought, for sure, oh my gosh, this is real!
Well, later I learned the truth of the matter.
I don’t think it was planned, or I don’t think it was fraudulent,
but it turned out we were right next to a military base
and they were out on maneuvers in the middle of the night. What I had witnessed were flares,
military flares, slowly
descending
n the desert. It looked like a formation of four UFOs. It turned out not to be at all,
but what a striking coincidence that it happened at the time and place specified by a trance
medium.
There are many other examples of this sort of synchronicity
associated with “almost”
UFO events. I could go on and on, the topic is really vast, but I
think I’ve given you a picture. I would say in conclusion that
parapsychologists ought to take a deeper interest in UFOs.
I think they’re afraid to because, you know, it’s bad enough to be involved in one controversial science,
to be involved in two
would be almost too much. It sort of reminds me of Sammy David, Jr., who was both black and Jewish.
“I got enough tsuris being Jewish, do I have to be black also?”
It’s like that, being both interested in parapsychology and UFOs, but in search of the truth
one has to do that. I think it’s very important to look for new
hypotheses, and to defy, you know, conventional thinking about this. And always
remember the trickster is probably right over your shoulder when you engage in this pursuit.
I’ll leave you with that thought.
Thank you for being with me.
You
